lexUnit.name: judge.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: decide the value or significance of some feature

sentence.text: ` You judge yourself too harshly , fräulein .
Women are still judged so much by their appearances , so we feel we have to get that perfect first , before achieving anything . "
If Kraus judged Vienna so harshly , what words could be severe enough for Berlin ?
People who complain about the failures of schools generally assume such a system , and indeed often judge schools by the examination results that they publish .
Today we all too often judge Hawaiian music by its most commercial format , the saccharine-sweet elevator fodder we all love to hate .
Tedious though this point may be , it is particularly in need of emphasis today , when the value of research is so often judged only by expected and short-term practical applications .
Do we judge them by the depth of their humanity , or by the extent to which they have reduced international tension ?
One can judge the age by length . "
Do n't judge me by your own standards .
However , referee Ford judged it to be a yellow card offence and the free-kick came to nothing .
It was all in one piece and could n't be opened , and she judged it as being thick enough to resist breaking , even under the impact of one of the chairs .

This was judged by patient history and counting residual tablets ( the placebo and ursodeoxycholic acid were given double blind ) when the prescriptions were renewed and compliance in taking the prescribed tablets were excellent .
You can judge the effectiveness of different methods by the number of eggs produced .
It may be misleading to judge capacity by how banks perform in a recession .
Such essays are usually judged to be lacking a necessary dimension for achieving high marks .
